qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I mainly use my phone for calling my contractor, co-workers, and family members. Sometimes the contractor sends work location details on WhatsApp. I also use YouTube to watch news and construction-related videos in the evening.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, sometimes I share my phone with my wife or children to make calls or watch videos. I don’t like sharing it with outsiders.

qa.question: What apps and features do you frequently use?
qa.answer: I use phone calls, WhatsApp, YouTube, the camera, and sometimes Google Maps if I go to a new work site. I also use UPI apps for small payments.

qa.question: Do you read app permissions before allowing them?
qa.answer: I read a little. I understand basic things like camera, location, and contacts. If it looks confusing, I just allow it so the app works.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app is safe to use?
qa.answer: If many people use it or if my co-workers recommend it, I feel it is safe. I don’t install apps from unknown links.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted messages, photos, or apps for privacy?
qa.answer: Yes, I delete work photos after sending them. I also delete WhatsApp forwards and videos when storage gets full.

qa.question: What do you do before giving your phone for repair?
qa.answer: I remove the SIM card and log out of payment apps. I don’t know how to fully clean the phone, so I feel worried.

qa.question: Have you asked someone for help with phone problems?
qa.answer: Yes, I ask my children, younger co-workers, or go to a mobile shop. Sometimes I try to fix small issues myself.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I trust my wife and close family members. I don’t share personal details with co-workers or strangers.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Yes, I save some contacts with short names so others don’t understand who they are.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: Yes, I helped another worker install WhatsApp and showed him how to send voice messages.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera, microphone, or location?
qa.answer: I know location can be turned off. I don’t know much about camera or microphone settings.

qa.question: What do you do when you get warning messages on your phone?
qa.answer: I read them carefully. If I don’t understand, I show them to my children or ask someone.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think the app can see those photos and numbers. I am not sure if they are stored somewhere else.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, because family photos, WhatsApp chats, and payment apps are there.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your photos or apps without asking?
qa.answer: Once, the repair person checked my gallery for storage. I didn’t like it, but I didn’t stop him.

qa.question: Do you use a lock screen on your phone?
qa.answer: Yes, I use a pattern lock and sometimes fingerprint.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones?
qa.answer: I don’t think about local or foreign. I think popular apps are safer.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand phone settings?
qa.answer: I ask my children or younger workers at the site.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my children and co-workers talk about scams and fake calls, so I am careful.

scenarios.Broken Phone: Before giving my phone for repair, I remove the SIM card and log out of payment apps. If possible, I delay repair until my children can help.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If my wife or children use my phone, I don’t mind. I close payment apps first.
scenarios.Installing a New App: I install apps only if needed for work or if someone I trust recommends them.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I help them make calls and open WhatsApp. I explain basic things but not permissions in detail.
scenarios.Using Someone Else’s Phone: I only use it for calls or messages and return it quickly.
scenarios.Giving Away Phone: I ask my children or a mobile shop person to delete everything before giving it away.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I know photos can be saved online, but I don’t know how to manage it properly. I will ask my children.
scenarios.Free Public WiFi: I sometimes use it but avoid opening payment apps.
scenarios.Lottery Call: I cut the call and block the number.
scenarios.Emergency Bank Transfer: I first call the person directly or check with my family before sending money.
